when the eating disorder is part of a relationship, there are many control issues at stake. (control, not self control). a friend of mine had the ultra thin wife (anorexic syndrome). but she wanted him to stay fat so that other women wouldn't find him too attractive. her game was to be the uber-cook. that way she controlled her own needs to feel both desirable and secure and indispensable. (she died; he lost the weight.)

i've dated a bulimic. didn't know that for a while. until the pattern emerged: he would ask for food or get up or raid the refrigerator in the middle of the night, then run out early in the morning to go home to his own place and throw up. his way of keeping the relationship from ever getting too close while also feeling that it wasn't "really him" rushing out. took him a long time to admit, he wouldn't have. one day i asked him straight out. allergic to me? or going home to throw up? he was surprised that i had figured it out and wanted me to know that it wasn't about me personally but yes, it was about being nervous about letting the relationship evolve.

people with such extreme disorders can be very expert at using them to control situations where they are afraid of being out of control. it goes beyond their own individual problems, as al-anon would say. the person they are closest to gets caught up in their chaos.

There's more to it than just the desire to be the “thin one.”
They also simply want to be around the food. Something that many don't understand about eating disorders is that in every form (bulimia, anorexia, binge eating), they are an addiction to food: food itself, thoughts about food, etc. So, the act of just being around the big portions of fatty food can "feed" the addiction.

All of you are forgetting (or simply ignore) that bulimia is an awful mental illness. Who has not experienced it cannot even imagine the pain, the depression, the self hatred, as well as the physical suffering behind this illness. Talking about people suffering with bulimia as selfish and vain individuals demonstrates ignorance. One does not choose to be bulimic, and certainly one does not get sick because he/she is vain or selfish.
As for the man who put on 50 lbs because his wife bullied him into eating, I frankly find the story ridiculous. You overate, you did not exercise, you did not take care of yourself or your wife, and that is how you ended up 50 lbs heavier. Maybe you could not get over the fact that you could not help your sick wife, and that must hurt a lot more than gaining 50 lbs.

Look up PANDAS and Strep on the internet.
In a small number of children, a bacterial strep infection is followed by a severe neuropsychiatric disorder. It's called PANDAS (Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections).
Strep causes several autoimmune reactions: heart valve damage, kidney damage, It seems obvious that other autoimmune damage can result. And more than that, if PANDAS is associated with the DR7 gene, like heart valve disease there are eight other bacteria who can cause the same damage. Lately I saw an article about Type 1 diabetes (autoimmune destruction of the pancreas) being caused by strep infections too.
Autoimmune disorders related to strep may abate with antibiotic treatment. But they might not. Sometimes the autoimmune disease will begin after the strep has been beat.

Let's have a periodic national referendum on the issues of the day. Let's start with one on the deployment of our military in Iraq, Afghanistan and every foreign outpost. Chris,

Thank you for choosing to discuss this in a civil manner, as opposed to those who spout nonsense.

I don't think I understand your square peg and a round hole comment. How is Afghanistan such a situation? You mention on several occasions that we can't change these countries from what they are. What is Afghanistan? If you look at Afghanistan, it was not always a war ravaged mess. The Soviet invasion certainly altered (literally and figuratively) the landscape of Afghanistan. However before this, Afghanistan was a country of religious tolerance, relative peace, and beginning a trend towards modernity. The policies of King Amanullah and later Zahir Shah helped mold Afghanistan into a nation with a modern constitution, parliament, universal suffrage, etc. If the Soviets never invaded, who knows how Afghanistan might have turned out. However, it's useless to speculate. Given the many changes Afghanistan has undergone in the 20th century, it's not out of the realm of possibility for a "Western Style Democracy" to exist.

Furthermore, it's incorrect for to say that we are trying to remake Afghanistan in our own image. While Afghanistan does have a bicameral legislature and a president, if you examine it's judicial branch and its laws, it certainly does not resemble anything that you'd see in the United States, Great Britain, or anywhere in the Western world. While there is a civil law code, the code can best be described as Shariah Law (of which there are several schools of jurisprudence...too complicated for a forum post). Furthermore, I believe a great deal of governance is convened through a "Loya Jirga" which essentially is a mass "tribal" counsel. That being said, Afghanistan's government is a combination of Islamic, Western and Tribal governance.

The premise of "government in a box" seems absurd to you and many others. However, it is necessary in such an operation. The government needs to be on the ground providing services for its people to maintain its legitimacy. While in practice it may not work, its essential for the Karzai government to be on the ground providing services and governance to achieve or maintain the loyalty of Afghans.

Your last comment is an irrelevant observation given our discussion. Afghanistan has been ravaged by 30 years of devastating warfare. After the Taliban were removed from power in 2001, the rebuilding process started from scratch. In essence, there were no institutions other than Islam to build upon. Because of this, you do not a massive widespread insurrection. The forces we face in Afghanistan are primarily Islamist groups such as the Taliban/Haqqani Network, Hezb-i-Islami (Gulbuddin) and al-Qaeda who are vying to recapture power in Afghanistan. America on the other hand has institutions and governance in place which have existed for over 200 years. To compare the two is apples and oranges my friend.

Tony, from 'The South' wrote, "Hmmm, i wonder if all the anti-US commenters on this blog would have a comfortable time inviting the Taliban to their house for dinner and some convivial political conversations."

No, Tony, I wouldn't be confortable inviting the Taliban to my house. And yes, I know they're wicked, wicked people. So what? There are hundreds of wicked groups all over the world, on every continent, in every country. What I want to know is why should such a huge percentage of my hard-earned tax dollars is being spent on useless military adventurism that has little to no chance of long-term success. I want people in my neighborhood to get a decent education and a decent job, so that they can have a decent life and not rob or kill me out of desperation. All the billions we spend on these useless adventures overseas may provide jobs to the military and defense contractors, but they do nothing about the infrastructural problems we have right here at home - problems we need to solve quickly if our society is going to stay even remotely healthy and competitive into the 21st century. It is not ANTI-USA to ask that teenagers and early 20-somethings in the prime of their life not DIE for some ill-defined mission of NATION-BUILDING in one of the poorest countries on earth.
